action.action-desc: Ms. DeLauro (for herself, Ms. Roybal-Allard, Mr. Conyers, Mrs. Dingell, Mr. Courtney, Ms. Norton, Mr. Hastings, Mr. Khanna, Ms. Kelly of Illinois, Mr. Kildee, Ms. Clarke of New York, Ms. Jackson Lee, Mr. Cummings, Ms. Wilson of Florida, and Ms. Wasserman Schultz) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Energy and Commerce

form.official-title: To amend section 317A of the Public Health Service Act to reauthorize a program for screenings and referrals regarding lead poisoning, and for other purposes.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Screen, Manage, Address, and Remove Toxins for Children Act of 2017 or the SMART Child Act of 2017.

section.header: Screenings and referrals regarding lead poisoning

subsection.text: Section 317A(d) of the Public Health Service Act (42 U.S.C. 247b–1(d)) is amended—

paragraph.text: by redesignating paragraph (8) as paragraph (9); and
by inserting after paragraph (7) the following:

subparagraph.text: A protocol for referring for medical (including mental health) treatment infants and children who are found to have elevated blood lead levels.
Such protocol shall include identification of a single agency that will be responsible for—

clause.text: case management for such infants and children through the later of—

subclause.text: the date that is 3 years after the infant or child is referred to the agency; and
if the infant or child continues to need services related to such elevated blood lead levels beyond the end of such 3-year period, the date on which the infant or child is discharged; and

clause.text: overseeing such referrals and ensuring that the infant or child and the family are receiving services deemed necessary by medical and mental health professionals.

subsection.text: Paragraph (1) of section 317A(l) of the Public Health Service Act (42 U.S.C. 247b–1(l)) is amended by striking $40,000,000 and all that follows through the period and inserting $150,000,000 for each of fiscal years 2018 through 2022..
